div.head: FIRST PART: THE CONQUEST OF TROY.
FIRST ACT
div.stage: The site of the abandoned Greek camp in the Trojan plain. To the left of the audience and some distance inside Troy, lies the Citadel. To the right, the Simoeis river, and on one of its banks, Achilles’ thumb. In the distance, the peaks of Mount Ida. An altar lies at the front of the stage, and next to it an elevated throne.

div.head: Nº 1 – Chorus of Trojans
div.stage: The Trojan people joyfully spread out on the plain. Soldiers, citizens, women, and children. Dances, various games. Three shepherds play the double flute on top of Achilles’ tomb.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Ha! Ha!
After ten years spent within our walls,
Ah! How joyful it is to breathe
The pure air of the fields, that will no longer be torn by battle cries.
sp.stage: Young men and children come running holding shards of weapons.
sp.l: What wreckage! An iron spear!
I found a helmet! – And I, two javelins!
Look, this huge shield!
It would float a man over water!
What cowards are these Greeks!

sp.speaker: A SOLDIER
sp.l: Do you know whose tent
Stood on this very site?

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: No! Tell us… Whose was it?

sp.speaker: THE SOLDIER
sp.l: That of Achilles.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.stage: Falling back, in terror
sp.l: Oh gods!

sp.speaker: THE SOLDIER
sp.l: Remain there, valiant troops!
Achilles is dead, you can see
His tomb, it is here.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: True, from this homicidal monster
Paris delivered us. – Do you know the wooden
Horse, that before departing for Aulis,
The Greeks built? This colossal horse,
Their offering to Pallas, a battalion would fit
Inside its vast guts. They are tearing down the city walls.
This evening we will drag it Into town;
They say the King will come soon to inspect it!
Where is it? – On the banks of the river Scamander!
We must see it without delay!
Let us run! Let us run! The horse! The horse!

div.stage: They leave, tumultuously

div.head: Nº. 2 -Recitative and Aria
div.stage: (As the previous scene ends, Cassandra has appeared among the people, striding the plain in agitation. Her gaze is restless and scattered.)

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: The Greeks have disappeared!… but what fatal intention
lies behind the strange haste of this departure?
All comes together to justify my somber disquiet.
I have seen the shadow of Hector striding our walls
Like a night sentry, I have seen his black gaze
scouring from a distance the strait of Sigeion…
Woe! Falling into madness and drunkenness
The crowd leaves the city walls, with Priam in the lead!
Unfortunate King! It is certain
You will descend into eternal night!
You will not listen to me; you refuse to understand,
Unfortunate people, the horror that pursues me.
Coroebus, alas, even Coroebus
Believes that I have lost my wits! At the mention of his name my dread
redoubles! Oh Gods! Coroebus! He loves me!
He is loved! But no more marriage for me.
No more love, no more joyous songs,
no more sweet tender dreams!
I must submit to the inexorable course
Of the frightful destiny that oppresses me.
sp.stage: She falls into a tender daydream
sp.l: Coroebus!… He must depart from Troy.

div.head: Nº 3 - Duet
div.stage: Coroebus arrives at a brisk pace

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: It is he!

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: While Troy is bursting with joy to the heavens,
You flee the joyful palaces
To the woods and fields, pensive forest nymph!
They are concerned about you…

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Ah! I hide from your eyes
The frightful dread that fills my soul!

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: Cassandra!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Leave me!

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: Come!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Leave, I entreat you!

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: Me, leave!
Leave you when the most sacred of ties…

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: It is the time to die and not to be happy.

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: Return to your senses, adored maiden!
Cease to prophesy and so cease to fear;
Raise towards the heavenly vault
The gaze of your comforted soul.
Let a sweet ray of hope enter your heart.

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: The heavens are full of menace. Believe my voice, inspired by the
same barbarian god who is intent on destroying us.
I have deciphered the book of destiny.
I see a swarm of evils unleashed upon us!
It will fall upon Troy!
Prey to its fury
The people will howl,
And their blood
Will stain the streets red;
Half-naked virgins
In the arms of their ravishers
Will utter screams
That will pierce the clouds!
Already the black vulture,
On the highest tower
Sings of the carnage!
All things fall apart! All things swim
In a river of blood.
And in your side
Lies a Greek sword!… Ah!
sp.stage: Coroebus supports for a moment in his arms a half-fainting Cassandra.

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: Poor lost soul!
Return to your senses, adored maiden, etc.

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Death already hovers in the air…
And I have seen the sinister flash
Of its cold murderous gaze!
If you love me, go away -
Leave!… Go and give to your father
The necessary support
In his old age,
Now useless to us.

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: Ah, if such evil should fall on us ,
Dear heedless one, with what kind of eye
Would my father look upon me,
If I fled from my betrothed
At a time of danger?
But the heavens and the earth,
Forgetful of war,
Proclaim your error.
The warm sweetness
Of the breeze’s breath
and the sea whose waves
Break so languidly
On the headlands of Tenedos;
These serene flocks
On the rolling plain
This happy shepherd singing
And these merry birds
Seem only to proclaim
Under the celestial vault,
And everywhere only spread
The hymn of peace.

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Misleading signs! Perfidious calm!
Death already hovers in the air…
And I have seen the sinister flash
Of its cold murderous gaze!
Leave us this evening,
Hear me, I entreat you,
Let dawn see you no more
Within our walls!
I am dying of fear
And my heart is tearing itself apart!
Leave tonight, leave tonight!

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: Leave you, tonight!
Cassandra! and I adore you!
Save me, I beg you,
From a terrible despair.
Do you want me then to die?
Pitiless, can you say:
Leave tonight, leave tonight!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: If you once found me worthy, Coroebus,
Of your noble love, you would leave!

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: In the name of the heavenly gods and of Erebus,
Cassandra, you must listen to me!
I fall at your feet,
Cassandra!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: I cede before such pain!
Oh, cruel gods!

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: Leave you, tonight! etc.

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Hear me, I entreat you, etc.
You are blind and deaf like them! You persist
In sacrificing yourself to your deadly love!?

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: I’ll not leave you!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: So the frightful day
Will see you fight alongside my brothers?

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: I’ll not leave you!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: So be it! Here is my hand
And my chaste marital kiss!
Remain! Jealous death
Prepares our nuptial bed for tomorrow.

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: Come! Come!

div.stage: He drags her after him, distraught

div.head: Nº 4. March and Hymn
div.stage: Enter Ascanius leading the children, Hecuba and the princesses, Aeneas leading the Trojan warriors, Priam and the priests.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Gods, protectors of the eternal city,
Accept our offerings of incense,
and of the happiness of your faithful people
Hear the cries!
Oh divine authors of our deliverance,
Gods of Olympus! Gods of the seas!
Rulers of the universe,
Accept the gifts of gratitude.

div.head: Nº 5 – Gloved combat.
div.stage: Dances and popular games.

div.head: Nº 6 - Pantomime.
div.stage: Andromache enters with heavy steps, holding Astyanax’s hand. They are in mourning, both wearing white clothes

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Andromache and her son!
Oh fate!
These cries of public joy…
sp.stage: Astyanax lays a basket of flowers at the altar. Andromache kneels beside him and prays for a few minutes.
sp.l: And this immense sadness,
This profound grief.
sp.stage: Andromache stands and takes her son to Priam’s throne.
sp.l: This speechless suffering!
sp.stage: She presents the child to the King and the Queen. She pulls Astyanax to her bosom and embraces him with a convulsive tenderness.
sp.l: Trojan wives and mothers weep at the sight…
sp.stage: Priam stands up and blesses the child. Hecuba blesses him in turn. The King and the Queen sit back on their thrones. Astyanax, intimidated, seeks refuge by his mother. Andromache’s painful emotion increases.

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.stage: passing by the back of the stage
sp.l: Alas! Save your tears,
Widow of Hector…
sp.stage: Andromache lowers her veil.
sp.l: Faced with future disasters
You will spill bitter tears…
sp.stage: Her tears overwhelming her, Andromache takes Astyanax’s hand and departs, passing in front of the various groups of Trojans. The crowd parts for them. Several Trojan women weep, hiding their faces on the shoulders of the neighboring men. The two leave with slow steps.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Ah!

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.stage: Comes running
sp.l: Oh King! A great crowd of people and soldiers
Flees and runs
Like an unstoppable torrent!
An unprecedented portent has just frightened them:
Laocoön, discerning some treacherous trick
In the handworks of the Greek, with an intrepid arm
hurled his javelin at the wood, incitng
The indecisive and vacillating populace
To burn it. But then, swollen with rage,
Two monstrous sea serpents advanced towards the shore,
fell upon the priest, and in their terrible coils
Entangled him, and burning him with their fiery breath,
and bathing him in bloody saliva,
They devoured him in front of our eyes.

sp.speaker: PRIAM, PANTHUS, COROEBUS, AENEAS, HELENUS, CASSANDRA, ASCANIUS, HECUBA, THE PEOPLE
sp.l: Dreadful punishment!
Mysterious horror!
At this terrifying story
My blood has turned to ice
A chill of terror
Convulses my entire being!
Lacoön! A priest!
The target of the gods’ ire,
Devoured alive by these hideous monsters!
Horror!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Oh, pitiful people!
Mysterious horror, etc.

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: May the goddess protect us,
Let us fight this new danger!
It is too true, Pallas has just avenged
A hideous sacrilege.

sp.speaker: PRIAM
sp.l: To appease her, follow my orders without delay.

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: Already set skilfully on wheels,
The horse is prepared, therefore let all accompany it
with due pomp towards the Palladium.
Let children, women, warriors lead this sacred object in procession,
paving the way with flowers,
And may the trumpet and the lyre
Accompany your songs into Troy!

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Let (…) in procession this sacred object, etc

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.stage: walking around the stage as if lost
sp.l: Woe!

sp.speaker: PRIAM, HECUBA, AENEAS, PANTHUS, COROEBUS, HELENUS
sp.l: Pallas, forgive Troy!
sp.stage: They exit. Cassandra stays alone in the proscenium. After taking a few steps in the direction of the crowd, she abruptly comes back.

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: No, I will not witness this deplorable party.
A people drunk with hopes of a dazzling future,
A doomed people, that cannot, alas, be saved
From the brink of the chasm. Oh cruel memories!
Glory of our country!… To see fading
The enticing image of the purest happiness!
Oh Coroebus! Oh Priam!… My courage is spent,
Tears of anguish pour down my face!

div.head: Nº 11 - Final: Trojan March
div.stage: The procession is heard from a great distance.

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Is this an illusion of my lost senses?
The sacred choruses of Ilion!

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Oh beloved daughter of the king of the gods,
Armed with your shield and your spear,
Wise warrior with a sweet gaze,
Look favourably on our destiny,
Make Ilion invincible,
Beautiful Pallas, protect us.

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: What, the procession is underway!… I see it in the distance!
The enemy is coming and the city is open!…
This crazed people running heedless to its doom
seems to have anticipated the King’s orders!
sp.stage: We hear the procession, closer.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Oh beloved daughter of the king of the gods, etc.
Hear our voices, oh sublime maiden,
Accompanied by Dindymus’s flutes,
Blend with the noblest of melodies.
May the Phrygian trumpet
Together with the Trojan lyre
Carry to you our devotional music!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: The sound of singing grows!
The enormous wheeled machine
Comes forth… here it is!

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.stage: Enters
sp.l: Oh beloved daughter of the king of the gods, etc.
Smiling wreath,
Around the offerings
Dance, happy children!
Scatter over the branches
The scented snow
Of the springtime lily-of-the-valley.
Pallas! Protect us!
sp.stage: The singing stops abruptly. The chorus shows agitation; some women exit, as if going to see what is happening off-stage; they return almost immediately.

sp.speaker: SOME TROJAN MEN
sp.l: What is happening? Why these starts of alarm?

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Jupiter! They hesitate!
And the crowd grows restless!

sp.speaker: THE WOMEN
sp.l: Inside the colossus we hear the sound of arms…

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: They are stopping… Oh gods… If…

sp.speaker: THE MEN
sp.l: Favorable auspices! Sing, children!
sp.stage: The chanting resumes more loudly than before.

sp.speaker: ALL THE CHORUS
sp.l: Proud peaks of Pergamus,
Shine triumphantly.
With a joyous flame,
sp.stage: The chorus follows the procession and exits.

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Stop! Stop! Yes, the flame, the axe!
Search the monstrous horse!
Lacoön!… the Greeks!… it conceals
An infernal trap…
My voice is lost!… all hope is lost!
You have no pity, great gods,
For this deluded people!
Oh what noble use of omnipotence,
to lead them into the abyss while covering their eyes!
sp.stage: She listens to the last sounds of the triumphal march which can still be heard, and which vanishes suddenly.
sp.l: They enter, it is done, destiny has its prey!
Sister of Hector,
Go to your death in the ruins of Troy!

div.stage: She exits.

div.head: Nº 12 - Scene and Recitative
div.stage: An apartment in Aeneas’ palace, barely lit by a lamp. Distant combat noise. Aeneas is asleep on his bed, half-armed. Ascanius comes out of a neighboring apartment, frightened. He listens; he approaches his father’s bed. The city noise fades; he dare not wake his father, and turns away from him. From a dark corner the bloody ghost of Hector advances slowly and solemnly towards Aeneas. His beard and hair are dirty and disheveled. Arriving by Aeneas, he remains motionless for a moment, looking at him, and sighs deeply. The noise of a collapsing building, louder than the previous ones, startles and awakens Aeneas. He sees Hector standing in front of him and after a moment of hesitation he addresses him, half rising from his bed..

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: Oh, light of Troy!… ¡Oh, glory of the Trojans!
After so much work by your fellow citizens,
From what unknown borders do you return? What cloud
seems to veil your serene eyes?
Hector, what woes have withered your face?

sp.speaker: THE GHOST OF HECTOR
sp.l: Ah!… flee, son of Venus!
The enemy holds our walls!
From their high ridge the whole of Troy crumbles!
A hurricane of flames unfurls
Its tainted eddies from temples to palaces…
Without fate’s decree, we could have done enough
To save the motherland. Pergamus entrusts you
With his children and his gods. Go, seek Italy…
Where for your reborn people,
After having erred for a long time over the waves,
You shall found a mighty empire,
That in the future will dominate the world,
And where a hero’s death awaits you.

div.stage: Hector departs solemnly, and his form becomes more and more blurry while Aeneas follows him with a look of alarm.

div.head: Nº 13 - Recitative and Chorus
div.stage: Enter Panthus, his face wounded, holding the gods of Troy.

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: What hope may we still have, Panthus?
Should we fight or flee?

sp.speaker: PANTHUS
sp.l: The blood-soaked city
Burns! Our doom is nigh!
Priam is no more! Issued from the monstrous horse,
the Greeks have massacred the guards at our gates,
and already innumerable cohorts,
Pouring in from outside, race all over
Fanning the flames
That shone light on their leaders’ vile treachery;
Others occupy the battlements.
sp.stage: Enter Ascanius

sp.speaker: ASCANIUS
sp.l: Oh, father! Ucalegón’s palace is collapsing!
Its roof is melting and falling like fiery rain!

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.stage: Interrupting him
sp.l: Follow us, Ascanius!
sp.stage: Coroebus enters, at the head of an armed troop.

sp.speaker: COROEBUS
sp.l: To arms, great Aeneas!
Come, the Citadel is surrounded
But still resists!

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: We need to reach it whatever the cost.
Though prepared to perish,
Let us attempt our defense.
The refuge of the vanquished lies in not awaiting rescue.
sp.stage: Loud noises and distant cries.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: The refuge of the vanquished lies in not awaiting rescue.
Can you hear
The towers crumbling? The devouring flame?
The roars of the Greeks?
Their crowd is still increasing in numbers.
Let us march! Our despair will aim our blows.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Though prepared to perish, let us attempt our defense,
the refuge of the vanquished lies in not awaiting rescue.
sp.stage: Aeneas takes Ascanius’s hand and places him in the middle of an armed group.
sp.l: Mars! Erinyes! Guide us!

div.stage: They exit.

div.head: Nº 14 - Chorus - Prayer
div.stage: Interior of Priam’s palace. In the back, a colonnade with a slightly elevated balcony opens over a much lower plaza. Between the columns we see Mount Ida in the distance. The altar of Vesta-Cybele is lighted. Polyxena, Trojan women, are around the altar. Some are kneeling, others sit on the ground, many lie on the terrace of the altar, face to the ground. All have an attitude of the deepest despair.

sp.speaker: CHORUS OF TROJAN WOMEN
sp.l: Ah!
Powerful Cybele,
Immortal goddess,
Mother of the unfortunate,
Render help to the Trojans,
Show favor to their efforts,
In this terrible time!
Save from dishonor
And from slavery
Their mothers, their sisters.
Break the ungodly weapons
Of treachery
In the very hands of the conquerors,
Powerful Cybele, etc.

div.head: Nº 15 - Recitative and Chorus
div.stage: Cassandra enters, her hair disheveled.

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Not all will perish. Worthy Aeneas
And his troops, thrice renewing combat,
Have freed our brave citizens
Immured in the Citadel.
Priam’s treasury is safe in Trojan hands.
Soon to be in Italy, where fate beckons them,
They will see built, even more powerful and beautiful,
A new Troy. They march towards Mount Ida.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: And Coroebus?

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: He is dead.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Cruel gods!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Before the altar of Vesta
I prostrate myself one last time.
I follow my young spouse. Yes, here is an end
To my useless life.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Oh, worthy sister of Hector!
Prophetess whom Troy accused of insanity!
Yesterday was still time to save us,
When she predicted this huge downfall!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Soon she will be no more.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Oh, despair! Oh, vain regrets!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: But you, frightened doves,
Can you consent
To this horrible slavery? And will you submit
Dishonored maidens and women,
To the conquerors’ brutal law?

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Must we banish all hope from our hearts?

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Hope! Oh unhappy ones!
In these luminous shadows,
Can you not see, can you not hear
The cruel Myrmidons who fill our streets
And those who guard the avenues of the palace?

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: All is ended; nothing can save us from their embraces!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: Nothing, say you? If you are driven by honor,
sp.stage: points to the gallery
sp.l: Why does this chasm, then,
Open before you?
sp.stage: Shows her dagger and points to the women’s belts
sp.l: For whom is this weapon and its silken bindings,
If not for you, women of Troy?
sp.stage: A small group remains silent, showing profound horror.

sp.speaker: A PART OF THE CHORUS
sp.l: Champion of love
And honor, you speak the truth! We will follow you!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: The break of day
Will not find us sullied by the Greeks!

sp.speaker: THE GREAT CHORUS
sp.l: No, Cassandra, we swear it!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: You will not be paraded in triumph?

sp.speaker: THE GREAT CHORUS
sp.l: Never! Never! We will die with you!

div.head: Nº 16 - Final
div.stage: The women confer together. Some of them take up lyres, and play and sing.

sp.speaker: THE GREAT CHORUS
sp.l: Partners in her glory,
Sharing her fate,
Let us, through our death,
Blight the victory of the Greeks
Pure and free we have lived.
On this fatal night
Pure and free we will descend
To the shores of Hades!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.stage: Talking to a small group
sp.l: You who tremble and keep silence,
Do you hesitate?

sp.speaker: A SMALL GROUP
sp.l: Ah! I tremble!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: What?! Would you endure a vile existence
Unworthy of great hearts?

sp.speaker: A SMALL GROUP
sp.l: Alas! To die, already!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.stage: explosively
sp.l: Go and prepare the table and the bed of your masters!
Slaves, away from us!

sp.speaker: A SMALL GROUP
sp.l: Have pity…

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA, THE GREAT CHORUS
sp.l: Shame on you!
Go down to those traitors,
Throw yourselves at their feet, clasp their knees!
sp.stage: With a violent expression of contempt
sp.l: Go and survive! Thessalians!
Shame on you! Go! You are not Trojans!
sp.stage: They chase them away. The small group moves silently backstage in front of the other women, and finally exits. All the others return to the stage in ever growing exaltation.

sp.speaker: THE GREAT CHORUS
sp.l: Cassandra, we wiil die with you!
We will not be violated by the Greeks,
We will not be paraded in triumph,
No, no, never, we swear.
sp.stage: Taking up their lyres again.
sp.l: Partners in her glory, etc.
Open up for us, black Pluto,
The gates of Tenarus!
Ring out, Charon,
Your funereal fanfare!

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.stage: in the greatest exaltation
sp.l: Coroebus! Hector! Priam!
King! Father! Brother! Lover!
I join you! Hear their oath.
Gods of Hades!
sp.stage: She seizes the lyre of a Trojan woman.
sp.l: Die worthy of glory,
And in sharing my fate
Let us through our death, etc.
sp.stage: A Greek chieftain enters towards the end of this scene; he advances quickly with his sword drawn, and stops in astonishment at the sight of the Trojan women.

sp.speaker: A GREEK CHIEFTAIN
sp.stage: while the Chorus finishes singing
sp.l: What?! With a lyre in their hands…
Despite myself I admire the sublime irony of this noble emotion.
Cassandra!… how beautiful she looks while singing of death,
Blue-eyed priestess of Bacchus, heady with harmonies!
sp.stage: A group of Greeks enters.

sp.speaker: SOLDIERS
sp.l: The treasure! The treasure! Give us the treasure!
sp.stage: They draw their swords at the women.

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA
sp.l: We despise your craven threat,
Monsters drunk on blood, foul and predatory band!
You will not quench, you thugs, your thirst for gold!
sp.stage: She stabs herself and gives the dagger to Polyxena.
sp.l: Take it! The pain is nothing!
sp.stage: Polyxena stabs herself in her turn. Cassandra holds herself up.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER GROUP OF GREEKS
sp.stage: Entering
sp.l: Enemy gods! Oh fury!
Blood-sodden, in the midst of the carnage,
Aeneas and his Trojans escape our blows.
And, masters of the treasure, they leave!…

sp.speaker: CASSANDRA, WOMEN
sp.stage: Some of the women undo their belts and draw their daggers.
sp.l: Despite your efforts,
They are all already on the paths of Ida,
And we brave your ire.
sp.stage: They all wave their veils and scarves towards Mount Ida.
sp.l: Save our sons, Aeneas!
Italy! Italy!

div.stage: Some jump from the balcony, others hang themselves or stab themselves. The Greeks shout in horror and run towards the colonnade. During this last scene, Cassandra, after stabbing herself and seeing the Trojans climb the balcony to jump down, advances staggering to the back of the stage; but her strength falters before she reaches the colonnade. She falls to her knees, and then by a supreme effort she stands again, and spreading her arms to Mount Ida, she shouts: Italy! and falls dead.

div.head: SECOND PART: THE TROJANS IN CARTHAGE.
THIRD ACT
div.stage: A vast green courtyard in Dido’s palace in Carthage. On one side sits a throne surrounded by trophies of agriculture, commerce, and arts; on the other side and at the back, a terraced amphitheater, where a large crowd is sitting, as the curtain rises.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.stage: one section of the Carthaginian people
sp.l: The heavens of Carthage seem to bless the festival!
Has there ever been such a day
After so fearful a storm?
How sweet is the breeze! Our blazing sun
Soothes the storm’s fury with its rays;
Beneath its orb the immense plain
thrills with joy; it moves though the sky
Lighting up the rosy smile
Of nature at its awakening.

div.head: Nº 18 – National Anthem
div.stage: Enter Dido with her court. When she enters, all the people seated in the amphitheater stand up and wave multicolored banners, palms, and flowers. Dido takes her seat on her throne with her sister on her right and Narbal on her left; some soldiers stand guard around her.

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHORUS
sp.l: Glory to Dido, our beloved queen!
She reigns by her beauty, grace, and wisdom;
She reigns with the blessing of the gods,
And by the love of her happy subjects!

div.stage: People wave palms and throw flowers.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.stage: Standing, from the height of her throne.
sp.l: It has been barely seven years,
Since the day when, to foil the ire
Of the tyrannical murderer of my august spouse,
I had to flee with you,
From Tyre to the African shore.
And already we see Carthage rise up,
Its fields in flower, its fleet complete!
Already from the distant shores where dawn rises,
You bring back, toilers of the sea,
Wheat, wine, wool, and iron,
And the goods that we still lack.
Dear Tyrians, such noble labours
Have intoxicated my heart with righteous pride.
But do not falter, heed the sublime voice
Of the God who urges you to strive anew!
Give yet another example to the earth;
Great in peace, become in wartime
A heroic people

sp.speaker: THE PEOPLE
sp.l: Great in peace, etc.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Fierce Iarbas wants to fetter me in the chains
Of a hateful marriage;
His arrogance is in vain.

sp.speaker: THE PEOPLE
sp.l: His arrogance is in vain.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: I count on you to defend me,
And on the gods.

sp.speaker: THE PEOPLE
sp.l: Glory to Dido, our beloved queen!
Each of us would lay down his life for her!
Together we will defend her.
We defy the arrogance and fury of Iarbas,
And we will drive back
To the end of the deserts this Numidian savage!

sp.speaker: DIDO, PEOPLE
sp.l: Dear Tyrians, such noble labours, etc.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: This beautiful day,
Which will remain always in your memory,
Has been dedicated by me
To crown the works of peace.
Approach, builders,
Sailors, farmers,
Receive from my hand the just reward
For the work that gives the State
Its power and its life.

div.head: Nº 20 – Entrance of the Builders
div.stage: The builders advance towards the throne. Dido gives their leader a silver set-square and an axe. The procession returns to the back of the stage.

div.head: Nº 21 – Entrance of the Sailors
div.stage: The sailors advance towards the throne. Dido gives their leader a helm and an oar. The procession returns to the back of the stage.

div.head: Nº 22 – Entrance of the Farmers
div.stage: The procession of the farmers, more numerous than the two preceding ones, advances slowly towards the throne; led by a hale old man

div.head: Nº 23 - Recitative and Chorus
div.stage: Dido gives to the aged leader of the farmers a golden sickle, and then, holding in her hands a wreath of flowers and ears of corn, she proclaims:

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: People! All honor
To the greatest of arts,
The art that feeds the people!

sp.speaker: THE PEOPLE
sp.l: Long life to the farmers! We are
Their grateful children; they give us bread!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.stage: Aside
sp.l: Oh, Ceres! The future of Carthage is secure!

sp.speaker: GENERAL CHORUS
sp.l: Glory to Dido, our beloved queen!
Each of us would lay down his life for her!
Let us prove our love for her through new
pledges. Settlers, sailors, let us become a heroic people!
Glory to Dido, our beloved queen!
She reigns by her beauty, etc.

div.stage: The people, led by Narbal, parade in procession before Dido’s throne, and exit.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: The happy songs, the sight of this noble festival,
Have restored peace to my troubled heart.
I breathe again, my sister, yes, my joy is perfect,
I return again to calm and serenity.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: Queen of a budding empire
That rises flourishing every day,
Beloved queen admired by the world
What fear has briefly disturbed you?

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: A strange sadness,
Without reason, as you know, overwhelms me at times.
I struggle in vain against this weakness,
A chill pierces my bosom, oppressed by vague troubles,
and burning tears sear my flushed face…

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.stage: Smiling
sp.l: You will love, my sister…

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: No, any new attachment
Is irrevocably forbidden to my heart.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: You will love, my sister…

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: No, the faithful widow
Must suppress her soul and shun love.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: Dido, you are queen, and too young, and too beautiful,
to defy the sweet rule of love;
Carthage needs a king.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.stage: Displaying Sychaeus’ ring on her finger
sp.l: May my people and the gods curse me,
If I ever remove this sacred ring!

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: Such an oath makes lovely Venus
Smile; the gods refuse
To note it in their sacred books.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Her words raise in my breast
A dangerous intoxication;
Already in my weakness,
I fight in vain an uncertain hope.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: My words raise in her breast
Dreams of tenderness;
Already in her weakness,
She fights in vain the sweet hope of love.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Sychaeus! Oh, my husband, forgive me
This brief involuntary failing
And may your memory banish from my heart
This unexpected turmoil.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: Dido, my tender sister, forgive me
If I dispel a fallacy too dear to you
Forgive me if my words create in your heart
This unexpected turmoil.

sp.speaker: IOPAS
sp.l: Barely saved from the angry sea,
Queen, the representatives of an unknown fleet
Beg admission to your presence.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: The doors of my palace are never barred
To such supplicants.
sp.stage: The queen dismisses Iopas; he exits.
sp.l: Wandering the seas,
Was I not also, from shore to shore,
Drawn into the eye of the storm
A plaything of the cruel seas!
Alas, I know the violence of fate’s blows
On those that it targets. Compassion for others’ woes
is easy for us. Those who have known pain
Cannot see others suffer in vain.

div.head: Nº 26 – Trojan March
div.stage: In the sad mode

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.stage: Aside
sp.l: I feel a sudden and vivid desire
To see them, and secretely I fear their presence.

div.stage: She takes a seat on her throne. Aeneas enters disguised as a sailor, Panthus, Ascanius and Trojan chieftains bear gifts.

sp.speaker: ASCANIUS
sp.stage: Bowing in front of the queen
sp.l: August queen, a wandering and unfortunate people
requests a few days of shelter.
I lay at your feet these precious gifts;
Remnants of a devoted leader’s greatness,
Offered in the name of Jupiter, by means of my weak hand.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Lovely child, tell me the name and nation of this commander.

sp.speaker: ASCANIUS
sp.l: Oh queen, our steps are stained with blood
On the paths from the Phrygian mountains
To the sea. This scepter of Iliona,
sp.stage: he offers the gifts one by one
sp.l: Daughter of King Priam, this crown of Hecuba’s,
And Helen’s fine veil glinting with gold,
Should tell you clearly that we are Trojans.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Trojans!

sp.speaker: ASCANIUS
sp.l: Our chief is Aeneas,
I am his son.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Strange fate!

sp.speaker: PANTHUS
sp.stage: Advancing
sp.l: Obeying the king of gods,
This hero seeks Italy,
Where fate has promised him a glorious death
And the joy of giving a country to his people.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Who can fail to admire this prince, friend of the great Hector?
Who is unaware of his famous name?
All Carthage speaks of nothing else.
Tell him that my port awaits his ships.
May you all come, may you forget
Your misfortunes in my court.

sp.speaker: NARBAL
sp.stage: Enters, perturbed
sp.l: I hardly dare announce such terrible news!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: What is happening?

sp.speaker: NARBAL
sp.l: The Numidian rebel,
Fierce Iarbas
With countless soldiers
Advances upon Carthage.

sp.speaker: CARTHAGINIANS
sp.stage: From a distance
sp.l: Arms! We need arms!

sp.speaker: NARBAL
sp.l: The savage troops
Butcher our herds
And raze our fields.
But new woes
Threaten the city itself:
Our young warriors
With their extreme ardor
Lack weapons

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: What are you saying, Narbal?

sp.speaker: NARBAL
sp.l: That we are planning to take part in an unequal combat.

sp.speaker: CARTHAGINIANS
sp.l: Arms! We need arms!

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.stage: Coming forward, no longer dressed as a sailor, he is clad in shining armor, but wears no helmet or shield.
sp.l: Queen, I am Aeneas!
My fleet, blown by the winds upon your shores,
Was destined by me for rugged deeds;
Permit the Trojans to fight alongside you!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: I accept such an alliance with pride!
Aeneas armed in my defense!
The gods are on our side.
sp.stage: Aside, to Anna
sp.l: Oh sister, how proud he is, this son of a goddess,
And how much grace and nobility we can see on his face!

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: Against this filthy horde of Africans,
Let us march, Trojans and Tyrians,
Let us fly to victory together!
Like grains of sand blown by the wind,
Let us drive into these fiery deserts
The wild Numidian; let him tremble.

sp.speaker: AENEAS, PANTHUS, NARBAL, IOPAS, ASCANIUS, DIDO, ANNA, TROJANS
sp.l: It is the god Mars who has gathered you/us together,
It’s the son of Venus who leads you/us into the fray!
Wipe out/let us wipe out the black army,
And tomorrow may public report
Proclaim in distant lands the shame and the death of Iarbas!
sp.stage: Towards the end of this scene, they bring Aeneas his arms. He quickly puts on his helmet, passes his arm through his massive shield and seizes his javelins.

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.stage: To Panthus.
sp.l: Announce to our Trojans the new venture
Where glory beckons.
sp.stage: Exit Panthus.
sp.l: Queen, soon from the odious barbarian
You will be free. To your generous care
I relinquish my son.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: For him be assured
Of a mother’s love.

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.stage: To Ascanius
sp.l: Come and embrace your father.
sp.stage: He embraces him, covering him entirely with his arms. Ascanius weeps silently.)
sp.l: Others will teach you, child, the art of being happy;
As for me, I will but teach you a warrior’s virtue
And respect for the gods;
But venerate in your heart and keep in your memory
The glorious examples of Hector and Aeneas.
sp.stage: The people of Carthage pour in from all sides demanding arms. Only some men are properly armed, the others hold sickles, axes, slings. Enter Panthus. Ascanius suddenly dries his tears and runs to the sides of the Trojan chieftains.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Arms! We need arms!
Against this filthy horde of Africans,
Let us march, Trojans and Tyrians, etc.

div.head: Nº 29 – Royal Hunt and Storm.
div.stage: An African forest by morning. At the back, a towering rock. To the left and at the foot of the rock, the mouth of a cave. A stream runs around the rock and flows into a natural pond bordered by bulrushes and reeds. Two naiads (river nymphs) appear for a brief moment before vanishing, then reappear swimming in the pond. Royal hunt. Horn fanfares sound from afar in the forest. The frightened naiads hide in the reeds. We see Tyrian hunters pass by, holding dogs on leads. Young Ascanius gallops across the stage on horseback. The sky turns dark; rain falls and becomes a growing storm. Soon the terrible tempest intensifies, with torrential rain, hail, lighting and thunder. The hunting horns sound in the midst of the tumultuous weather. The hunters scatter; and finally we see Dido, dressed as Diana the huntress, holding a bow, with a sheath of arrows over her shoulder, and Aeneas in semi-military dress. They are both on foot. As they enter the cave, wood nymphs appear atop of the rock, their hair disheveled, and run back and forth, shouting and gesticulating wildly. In the midst of their clamor, we can at times make out the word: Italy! The stream swells and becomes a noisy torrent. Several other waterfalls surge at various points of the rock, and add their noise to the crashing of the storm. In the darkness satyrs and wood people dance grotesquely with the fauns. Lightning strikes a tree, shatters it and sets it on fire. Fragments of the tree fall upon the stage. The satyrs, fauns, and wood people, still dancing, take up the burning branches, then together with the nymphs vanish into the depths of the forest. The storm recedes. The clouds lift.
The gardens of Dido, by the sea, at sunset.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: Tell me, Narbal, what is it that alarms you?
That day that ended war and its woes
Did it not witness the brilliant glory of our arms?
Are the Tyrians not victorious?

sp.speaker: NARBAL
sp.l: We have nothing more to fear on that account;
The Numidians were driven back to their sandy deserts;
no more will they appear at our walls;
And the mighty sword
Of the invincible hero
Has delivered us from Iarbas.
But Dido now neglects
The tasks that were previously so dear to her;
In hunting and partying she spends her days;
Public works are deferred, the workshops are empty,
the long sojourn of the Trojans in Carthage
Causes me cares that are shared by the people.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: Ah! Can you not see, Narbal, that she loves
This fierce warrior, and that he too experiences
For my sister an equivalent love?

sp.speaker: NARBAL
sp.l: What?!

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: What do you fear from
The passion that moves them?
Could Dido find a braver husband, and
Carthage a more magnanimous king?

sp.speaker: NARBAL
sp.l: But insistent fate
Summons Aeneas to Italy!

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: One voice tells him: Leave!
Another voice urges: Stay!
Love is the greatest of the gods.

sp.speaker: NARBAL
sp.l: With what setbacks do you threaten Carthage,
O gloomy future?
I see foreboding lightning bolts
Issuing from the heart of your cloud!
Jupiter! God of hospitality,
In demonstrating a virtue dear to your heart,
Have we therefore earned
The blows of your rage?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: Useless fears!
Carthage is triumphant!
Our charming queen
Loves a victorious hero,
A garland of flowers entwines them;
Soon they will be united.
Such the threat
Of your gloomy future.

div.head: Nº 32 – March for the Queen’s entrance
div.stage: over the theme of the National Anthem
Enter Dido, Aeneas, Panthus, Iopas and Ascanius. Dido takes a seat with Anna on a platform, with Aeneas and Narbal close to her.

div.head: Nº 33 - Ballets
div.stage: a) Pas des Almées
b) Danse des Esclaves
c) Pas d’Esclaves nubiennes

sp.speaker: NUBIAN SLAVES
sp.l: Ah! Ah!
Amaloué
Midonaé
Faï caraïmé
Deï beraïmbé
Ah! Ah!

div.stage: The queen descends from the platform and reclines on a couch in the proscenium, with her left profile to the audience. At first Aeneas remains upright.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.stage: languidly
sp.l: Enough, my sister, I can tolerate no more
These importunate festivities…
sp.stage: Anna waves away the ballerinas.
sp.l: Iopas, sing for us,
In simple and sweet mode,
Your pastoral poem.

sp.speaker: IOPAS
sp.l: I obey
The queen’s order.
sp.stage: A Theban harpist stands close to Iopas to accompany him. The harpist is attired as an Egyptian priest.
sp.l: Oh, fair Ceres!
When to our fallow fields
You restore their crown
Of fresh greenery
How happy you make us!
The gratitude
Of the aged farm-hand,
Of the young shepherd,
Gives thanks for the abundance
That you pledge to them.
Oh, fair Ceres, etc.
The shy bird,
The playful lamb,
The soft breath
Of the prairie winds,
All praise your virtues.
Fruitful Ceres, etc.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.stage: Interrupting him
sp.l: Forgive me, Iopas, even your voice,
In my extreme unease,
Fails to beguile me this evening…

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.stage: seats himself at Dido’s feet
sp.l: Dear Dido!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Aeneas.
Ah! deign to finish
The tale you started
Of your long journey
And of Troy’s woes.
Relay to me the fate
Of beautiful Andromache…

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: Alas! Reduced to slavery
By Pyrrhus,
She begged for death;
But the steadfast love
This prince bore her
Finally rendered her unfaithful
To the warmest of memories…
After lengthy resistance,
She wed Pyrrhus.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: What?! Hector’s widow!

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: Thus she ascended
To the throne of Epirus.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Oh, propriety!
sp.stage: Aside.
sp.l: Everything conspires
To dispel my doubts and absolve my heart.
sp.stage: Ascanius, leaning on his bow and looking like a statue of Love [Cupid], stands to the left of the queen; Anna, leans over with her elbow resting on the back of Dido’s couch. Next to Anna stand Narbal and Iopas.
sp.l: To think that Andromache wed the man who slew her father,
the son of the murderer of her illustrious husband!

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: She loves her conqueror,
The man who slew her father,
The son of the murderer of her illustrious husband!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Everything conspires, etc.
sp.stage: As Dido rests her left arm on Ascanius’ shoulder, her hand hanging over the child’s chest, he laughingly removes Sychaeus’ ring from the queen’s finger. Seemingly distracted, Dido takes it back, and forgets it on the couch as she rises.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.stage: Pointing to Ascanius.
sp.l: See, Narbal, as this child
Resembling Cupid, with light touch
Gently steals from Dido
The ring that she reveres.

sp.speaker: IOPAS Y NARBAL
sp.l: See, Narbal, as this child, etc.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.stage: daydreaming
sp.l: The son of the murderer of her illustrious husband!…
Everything conspires, etc.

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: Dido sighs…
But her doubts fly away,
And her heart is absolved!…
Dido sighs…
But her heart, yes, her heart is absolved.

sp.speaker: ANNA, IOPAS AND NARBAL
sp.l: Everything conspires, etc.

div.head: Nº 36 - Recitative and Septet

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: But let us banish these sad memories.
sp.stage: He stands up.
sp.l: What a resplendent night full of charm!
Come, dear Dido, breathe in the sighs
Of this breeze that caresses.

div.stage: Dido rises in her turn

sp.speaker: DIDO, AENEAS, ASCANIUS, ANNA, IOPAS, NARBAL, PANTHUS, CHORUS
sp.l: Only peace and delight surround us!
Night spreads its veil, and the sleeping sea
Croons sweet harmonies in its repose.

div.stage: All, except Aeneas and Dido, gradually exit from backstage, until they are all gone.

div.head: Nº 37 - DUET
div.stage: Moonshine

sp.speaker: DIDO, AENEAS
sp.l: Endlessly intoxicating night of ecstasy!
Golden Phoebe, and you, great stars of her court,
Shine upon us your blessed light;
Heavenly flowers, smile upon eternal love!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: On such a night, crowned with golden laburnum,
Your mother Venus followed the fair Anchises
To the groves of Mount Ida.

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: On such a night, headlong in joyous love,
Troilus came to the foot of Troy’s walls
To await the lovely Cressida.

sp.speaker: DIDO, AENEAS
sp.l: Endlessly intoxicating night of ecstasy!
Golden Phoebe, etc.

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: On such a night, chaste Diana
Finally shed her diaphanous veil,
In the sight of Endymion.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: On such a night the son of Cythera
Received coldly the rapturous tenderness
Of Queen Dido!

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: And on the same night, alas! the unjust queen,
Accusing her lover, obtained from him with ease,
The sweetest of forgiveness.

sp.speaker: DIDO, AENEAS
sp.l: Endlessly intoxicating night of ecstasy, etc.
sp.stage: They stroll slowly to the back of the stage, embracing; then, still singing, they exit. Just as the two lovers, now out of sight backstage, come to the end of their song, Mercury suddenly appears, bathed in a ray of moonlight, close to a broken column on which hang Aeneas’ weapons. Approaching the column, he strikes the shield twice with his staff, giving forth a prolonged and lugubrious sound.

sp.speaker: MERCURY
sp.stage: in a solemn voice, extending his arm out to sea.
sp.l: Italy! Italy! Italy!

div.stage: He exits.

div.head: First Tableau
div.stage: The seaside camp full of Trojan tents. We see the Trojan ships in the port. It’s night. A young Phrygian sailor sings while he swings from the top of a ship mast. Two sentries guard the tents, at the back of the stage.

div.head: Nº 38 – Hylas’ Song

sp.speaker: HYLAS
sp.l: Resonant valley,
Which, at dawn.
singing, I would visit, alas
Will poor Hylas
Ever sing again in your great woods?
Softly cradle Dindymus’s child
On your sublime breast, oh mighty sea!
Fresh leafy boughs,
Beloved refuge
From the blazing day, alas!
When will you again spread your scented shade
Over poor Hylas?
Softly cradle Dindymus’s child
On your sublime breast, oh mighty sea!
Humble cottage,
Where I received
My mother’s farewell.

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.l: He is dreaming of his country…

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.l: Which he will never see again.

sp.speaker: HYLAS
sp.l: Alas!
Will he see again his cheerful poverty,
Poor Hylas?…
Softly cradle Dindymus’s child
On your sublime breast, oh mighty sea!

div.stage: He falls asleep.

div.head: Nº 39 - Recitative and Chorus
div.stage: Enter Panthus and other Trojan chieftains.

sp.speaker: PANTHUS
sp.l: Prepare everything, we must leave at last.
In vain does Aeneas
Behold with despair the queen’s anguish,
Glory and duty will shatter his fetters,
and his heart Will be steadfast at the moment of parting.

sp.speaker: PANTHUS, CHIEFTAINS
sp.l: Each passing day sees the gods’ ire grow.
Fearsome signs already forewarn us;
The sea, the mountains, the deep woods groan;
Our weapons resound from invisible blows,
As in Troy on that fatal night,
Hector, with his wrathful gaze,
In armor appears; a horde of shades succeeds him,
and these exasperated ghosts,
Only last night thrice cried …

sp.speaker: THE GHOSTS
sp.l: Italy! Italy! Italy!

sp.speaker: PANTHUS, CHIEFTAINS
sp.l: Vengeful gods! It is their voice!…
Too long have we defied the heavenly orders;
Let us depart without delay from these baneful shores!
Tomorrow! Tomorrow!
Let us prepare, we must finally go.

div.stage: They enter their tents.

div.head: Nº 40 - Duet
div.stage: The two sentries march, one from right to left, the other from left to right. They halt sometimes close to each other in the middle of the stage.

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.l: In the name of Bacchus! They are mad with their Italy!
I heard nothing!

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.l: Neither did I.

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.l: And to think of the beautiful life, though,
That we lead here!

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.l: In more than one home
We find both good wine and abundant meat.

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.l: I have already learned how to speak Phoenician
To my beautiful Carthaginian woman.

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.l: Mine understands Trojan,
And she obeys me without complaint.

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.l: Yours understands Trojan?

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.l: She obeys me without complaint.
These women are not ill-disposed to foreigners.

sp.speaker: BOTH
sp.l: No! These women are not ill-disposed to foreigners.

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.l: And they wish us to exchange
This soft life for a lengthy voyage!

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.l: The storm’s embrace!

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.l: Hunger.

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.l: Thirst.

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.l: Twenty infernal woes!

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.l: And all the troubles of the sea!

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.l: Cursed folly!

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.l: For this Italy…

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.l: Where we are to enjoy the fruits of our labours …

sp.speaker: BOTH
sp.l: With backbreaking work!

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.l: To suffer, again!

sp.speaker: FIRST SENTRY
sp.l: To suffer, again!
Our fate is to obey.

sp.speaker: SECOND SENTRY
sp.l: Silence!
I see Aeneas striding towards us.

div.stage: The two sentries leave.

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.stage: Enters, highly agitated.
sp.l: Futile regrets!… I must leave Carthage!
Dido knows it… her fear, her shock
In learning it, breached my courage…
But I must go!… It is essential!…
No, I cannot forget the palor
Rising in her face like death,
Her unyielding silence, her fixed gaze
Full of melancholy fire…
In vain did I speak of the countless great feats
Imposed upon me by the gods,
I invoked the greatness of my sacred undertaking,
The future of my son and the fate of Trojans,
My triumphal death assured by destiny,
Which will crown my glory on the Ausonian fields;
Nothing could touch her;
I fled from her awful eloquent gaze, without breaching her silence.
Ah! When the moment comes for the final farewells,
a time of anguish, bathed in tears,
How will I endure the dreadful sight
Of this indignant grief?…
I must struggle with myself and also with you, Dido!
And beg for forgiveness while breaking your heart!
Could I do it? Ah! Better to perish at last
In a shipwreck, than to leave Carthage
Without seeing you once more!…
Without seeing her? Cowardice!
Such contempt for the inviolate laws of hospitality!
No, no, beloved queen,
Sublime soul that I have torn asunder,
Oh beloved queen! No, I will see you again,
One last time clasp your trembling hands,
Shed my burning tears at your feet,
Even if such despair leads to my downfall.

sp.speaker: CHORUS OF GHOSTS
sp.l: Aeneas!…

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: Those voices, again!
sp.stage: Four veiled ghosts appear one by one; one from stage right, another from stage left, and the other two from backstage. On each ghost’s brow shines a crown of small pale flames.

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: Menacing messengers from the shadows,
What then drew you forth?

sp.speaker: GHOST OF PRIAM
sp.stage: visible
sp.l: Your weakness and your glory…

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: Ah! better to die!

sp.speaker: GHOST OF PRIAM
sp.l: No more delay!

sp.speaker: GHOST OF COROEBUS
sp.stage: Invisible.
sp.l: Not one day further!

sp.speaker: GHOSTS OF HECTOR Y CASSANDRA
sp.stage: Invisibles.
sp.l: Not one hour more!

sp.speaker: GHOST OF PRIAM
sp.stage: lifting his veil before Aeneas.
sp.l: It is I, Priam! you must depart and still live!
sp.stage: His crown of fire dies out and he vanishes. Aeneas, distraught, rushes to the right of the stage, and there encounters the ghost of Coroebus.

sp.speaker: GHOST OF COROEBUS
sp.stage: removes his veil
sp.l: It is I, Coroebus!
You must leave and conquer!
sp.stage: His crown of fire dies out and he vanishes. Aeneas, moving to the back of the stage, encounters the other two ghosts. Cassandra has her left arm on Hector’s shoulder. Hector is armed from head to toe.

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.stage: recognizing them when they remove their veils
sp.l: Hector! Gods of Erebus!
Cassandra!

sp.speaker: GHOSTS OF CASSANDRA AND HECTOR
sp.l: You must conquer and found!…
sp.stage: Their crowns of fire die out, they vanish.

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: I must obey
Your ruthless orders!
I obey, I obey, o inexorable ghosts!
Great gods, you force me to be an ungrateful brute!
And I must sacrifice Dido, while averting my gaze!

div.head: Nº 43 - Scene and Chorus

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.stage: Passing before the tents
sp.l: To your feet, Trojans, awaken, be alert!
The wind is favorable, the sea beckons us!
Awaken!
We must depart before daybreak!

sp.speaker: THE TROJANS
sp.stage: from inside the tents.
sp.l: Be alert!… Do you hear, friends, the voice of Aeneas?
sp.stage: They come out of the tents.
sp.l: Sound the reveille in all parts…

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.stage: to a chieftain
sp.l: Go, hurry, relay this order to the astonished attention
of Ascanius. He must rise and board the ship!
We must leave the port before break of day.
My task, o great gods, will be finally
accomplished. Be alert, friends! Let us not waste a moment!
Slash the ropes, it is time!
To sea! To sea! Italy! Italy!

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: This is the day, let us not waste a moment!
Slash the ropes, it is time!
To sea! To sea! Italy! Italy!

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.stage: Turns to Dido’s palace.
sp.l: Farewell, my soul! Worthy of your forgiveness,
I leave, noble Dido!
Impatient fate summons me;
To die as a hero, I am unfaithful to you.

div.stage: All rush from the stage in various directions, making preparations to depart. We see the ships start to move off. There is lighting and thunder in the distance.

div.head: Nº 44 - Duet and Chorus

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Wandering in your footsteps,
In the rumbling thunderstorm,
I wanted to see, and now I watch in disbelief…
Are you preparing to flee?

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: In my profound grief,
Dear Dido, spare me!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: You are leaving? You are leaving?
Without remorse! What!?
Contemptuous of the scepter of Libya,
Ripping out my heart, you flee to Italy!

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: I have tarried too long…
The sovereign orders from the gods…

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: He departs! He follows the call of implacable fate,
Without heeding my voice! He lets me expose
My overwhelming grief to his cowardly disdain.
sp.stage: She sees a group of Trojans sneering at her
sp.l: And my majestic beauty
To the insolent sniggers of these ungrateful Trojans!

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: Dido!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Does the sight of such misery not bring
A tear of pity to his moisten his eye!
Do you leave? No! it was not Venus who bore you!
Some foul she-wolf suckled you in the forest!

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: O Queen, when I consigned you my soul,
I became subject of to the sway of an immortal love,
and to the end of my days,
My heart will burn with this flame…

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Silence! Nothing can stop you,
Not death that hovers above my head,
My shame, my love, our union just begun,
My name struck forth today from the golden book.
Yet had I a tender pledge of your faith,
Yes, if a son of Aeneas
With his noble tender features
Lay smiling on my breast,
I would feel less abandoned…

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: I love you, Dido, have mercy! Only a divine command
could thus be so cruelly victorious.
sp.stage: We hear the fanfare of the Trojan March.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: At this triumphal march where your glory shines,
I see you quiver!
Are you leaving?

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: I must leave…

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Are you leaving?

sp.speaker: AENEAS
sp.l: To obey the gods,
I go only to my death,
I am leaving and I love you!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Do not let my tears delay you further,
You monster of righteousness!
Go, then, go! I curse both you and your gods!
sp.stage: She exits.
Groups of Trojan soldiers busy preparing to leave, pass by on their way to the ships.

sp.speaker: AENEAS, THE TROJANS
sp.l: Italy!

div.stage: A Trojan chieftain leads in Ascanius. Aeneas boards a ship.

div.head: Second Tableau
div.stage: Dido’s chambers. Daybreak.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Go and beg him, my sister,
Pride has deserted
My despairing soul. Go! This departure kills me
As I see him preparing to leave.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: Alas! I was the guilty party,
When I encouraged you to form new ties.
Can we contest the gods’ will?…
His departure is inevitable,
And yet he loves you.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: He loves me?! No! No! His heart is made of ice!
Ah! I know love, and even if Jupiter himself
Had forbidden my love, my burning passion
Would have braved his curse.
But go, my sister, go, Narbal, beg him
To grant me yet
A few days more. Humbly I beg him:
Can he forget all I did for him ,
And, wise Narbal, would he reject your paramount authority,
and yours, my sister, whom he loves?…

div.head: Nº 46 - Scene

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.stage: from afar, backstage
sp.l: Look, six ships! Seven! Nine! Ten! At sea!

sp.speaker: IOPAS
sp.stage: Entering.
sp.l: The Trojans have left!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: IOPAS
sp.l: Before dawn,
Their fleet went to sea, they are still in sight!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Immortal gods! To arms, Tyrians!
Carthaginians, hurry, pursue the Trojans!
Strive with your oars,
Glide over the sea,
Hurl flames at them,
Burn their vessels!
May the entire city…
What am I saying? Futile rage!
Endure your fate and despair,
Consume your own grief,
Oh unhappy woman!
And this is, then, the troth of that dutiful soul!
I offered him a throne… Ah, I should instead
Have exterminated the wandering race
Of these accursed men, and scattered on the waves
the remnants of their bodies!
That was the time to foresee their treachery
and set fire to their fleet,
And take vengeance on Aeneas by serving him
The limbs of his son in a grisly banquet!
Help me, gods of Hades! Olympus is immovable!
Help me! Light in my heart the flames
Of a terrible hatred
For this fugitive that once I loved!
Let the priest of Pluto be summoned!
To bring peace my transports of grief,
Let us offer directly a sacrifice
To the grim deities of the kingdom of the dead!
Let a pyre be built!
May the gifts of the traitor
And those that I gave him
Be consumed, detested memories,
By the blazing flames!… Leave!

sp.speaker: NARBAL
sp.stage: To Anna.
sp.l: Her gaze terrifies me, oh princess! Stay with her!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Anna, follow Narbal!

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: May my sister forgive me!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: I am your queen and this is my order;
Leave me alone, Anna.

div.stage: Anna, Narbal and Iopas exit.

div.head: Nº 47 - Monologue
div.stage: Dido walks around the stage tearing her hair, beating her breast and shouting wordlessly.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Ah! Ah!
sp.stage: She stops suddenly.
sp.l: I will die…
Drowning in intense grief
I will die without being avenged!…
Let me die, then. Yes, may he shudder
At the distant glow of the flames of my pyre!
If there is still something human left in his soul,
Perhaps he will weep over my dreadful fate.
He, grieve for me!…
Aeneas!… Aeneas!…
Oh, my soul follows you,
Bound to your love,
Which, enslaved, it draws into eternal night…
Venus! Restore your son to me!… Futile prayer
Of a breaking heart!… Until the end,
Dido can hope for nothing more than death.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Farewell, proud city, which a communal effort
So rapidly built and made it blossom
Farewell my sweet sister who followed me blindly,
Farewell, my people, farewell, farewell, hallowed land,
that once welcomed my entreaties,
Farewell, beautiful African sky, its stars that I admired;
Farewell to endlessly intoxicating nights of ecstasy!
I will see you no more, my life journey has ended!…
sp.stage: She exits slowly.

div.head: Nº 49 – Funeral ceremony
div.stage: Dido’s gardens by the sea. A vast pyre has been built, with steps leading to it. On the platform of the pyre, there is a bed, a toga, a helmet, a sword and sheath, and a bust of Aeneas.

Enter the priests of Pluto, clad in mourning; they proceed in and stand next to the two altars, where greenish flames shine, followed by Anna, Narbal, and finally a veiled Dido crowned with leaves. During the beginning of the priests’ chorus, Anna, approaching her sister, unties her hair and removes her left cothurnus [laced boot].

sp.speaker: CHORUS OF THE PRIESTS OF PLUTO
sp.l: Gods of forgetfulness, gods of Tenarus,
Restore strength and peace to this wounded heart!
From the depths of black Tartarus,
Hear us, Hecate, Erebus, and you, Chaos!

sp.speaker: ANNA, NARBAL
sp.stage: opening their arms to the sea
sp.l: If Aeneas must land in Italy,
May he die there unrecognized!
May the Latin people ally with the Umbrians
To arrest his course!
Pierced by a common arrow in the heat of battle,
May he languish abandoned on the bloody battlefield,
to serve as carrion for ravening birds!
Hear us, Hecate, Erebus, and you, Chaos!

sp.speaker: PRIESTS, ANNA, NARBAL
sp.l: Gods of forgetfulness, gods of Tenarus, etc.

div.head: Nº 50 - Scene

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.stage: As though in a dream
sp.l: Pluto… seems to be propitious…
At this cruel moment… Narbal… my sister…
All is ended… let us make the reverent sacrifice…
I feel peace … return to my heart.
sp.stage: Two priests carrying the first altar advance from left to right; two others carrying the second move from right to left and circle the pyre, their paths crossing. Dido, with her left foot bare and her hair disheveled, after placing her crown of leaves on one of the altars, follows them with halting steps. During this procession, Anna kneels to the right of the stage with Narbal to the left. Between them, the great priest of Pluto, standing, stretches out with both hands the forked staff of Pluto towards the pyre. Finally, full of manic energy, Dido rapidly mounts the steps of the pyre. Arriving at the top, she seizes Aeneas’ toga, removes the golden veil from her head, and throwing them both onto the pyre, she says:
sp.l: Baneful tokens of an unhappy love,
Carry my woes with you into the fire!
sp.stage: She contemplates Aeneas’ weapons.
sp.l: Ah!
sp.stage: She prostrates herself on the bed, which she embraces with convulsive sobs. She rises, and taking up the sword, says in a tone of prophesy:
sp.l: My memory will live in future ages.
My people will do heroic deeds.
One day on African land,
A glorious avenger will rise from my ashes…
I hear already this conqueror’s name.
Hannibal! Hannibal! My soul is full of pride!
Let there be an end to bitter memories!
This is how it is proper to descend into Hades!

div.stage: She unsheathes the sword, stabs herself, and drops onto the bed.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Ah! Help! Help! The queen has stabbed herself!
sp.stage: Narbal leaves, as if seeking help.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.stage: rushing in from backstage
sp.l: What cries! ah! drenched in her own blood
The queen is dying!
sp.stage: Narbal comes back, the great chorus enters.
sp.l: Can it be true? Day of horror!

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.stage: sits up, leaning on her elbow.
sp.l: Ah!
sp.stage: She falls again.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.stage: over the pyre.
sp.l: My sister!
sp.stage: Dido rises.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Ah!
sp.stage: She lifts her eyes to heaven and falls again, groaning.

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.l: It is I,
It is your sister who calls you…

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.stage: Half-rises.
sp.l: Ah! The implacable anger of hostile fate!
Carthage will fall!

div.head: Nº 52 - Curse
div.stage: We see in distant glory the Roman Capitol; on its facade gleams the word Rome. Legions and an emperor march past the Capitol, surrounded by a court of poets and artists. During this apotheosis, which the Carthaginians cannot see, we hear from afar the Trojan March passed down by tradition to the Romans, which has become their triumphal chant.

sp.speaker: DIDO
sp.l: Rome… eternal… Rome!
sp.stage: She falls dead. Anna falls fainting by her side. The people of Carthage, advancing towards the proscenium and turning their backs to the pyre, hurl a curse, the first Punic battle-cry, in furious contrast to the solemn ceremony.

sp.speaker: CHORUS
sp.l: Eternal hatred to the race of Aeneas!
May a bloody conflict
Ever pitch our sons against theirs!
May our ships sink theirs,
Shattered into a thousand pieces
In the deep sea! May the last of our descendants
Ever taking arms against them, by land and by sea,
One day appall the world with their massacre!

div.head: Nº 52b – Original finale [replaced by the definitive text starting with Dido’s last line in Nº 52]
div.stage: A rainbow forms over the pyre, and a ray of sunlight split into the colors of the prism falls on Dido’s body.

sp.speaker: THE GREAT PRIEST
sp.l: As she dies, the faithful one
Rouses the pity of the gods;
sp.stage: Iris appears in the air and flies over the pyre, scattering poppies over the dying queen. All prostrate themselves before divine Iris.
sp.l: Iris descends from the heavens
To bring her death pangs to an end.
sp.stage: The rainbow vanishes along with Iris, but not the ray of sunlight.
sp.l: Repeat with me
the sacred incantation:
O suffering soul, breathe your last…

sp.speaker: NARBAL, CHORUS
sp.l: Suffering soul, breathe your last…

sp.speaker: THE GREAT PRIEST
sp.l: In the name of the gods, be free from your body.

sp.speaker: NARBAL, CHORUS
sp.l: In the name of the gods, be free from your body.
sp.stage: The ray fades. Dido dies. Anna falls fainting beside her.

sp.speaker: THE GREAT PRIEST
sp.l: She is no more, the queen has breathed her last!

sp.speaker: NARBAL, THE GREAT PRIEST, CHORUS
sp.l: Over her pyre and by her royal blood
Let us consecrate today the standard of Carthage!
May the same oath bind all of us here
To an inevitable fate!
Hatred to the race of Aeneas!
May a bloody conflict
Ever pitch our sons against theirs!
May our ships sink theirs,
Shattered into a thousand pieces
In the deep sea! May the last of our descendants,
Ever taking arms against them, by land and by sea,
One day appall the world with their massacre!

sp.speaker: EPILOGUE
sp.stage: A screen is lowered to the fore of the stage, symbolizing Time followed by the procession of the hours, twelve in pink and white gowns, and twelve in black gowns with golden stars. We hear a mysterious murmur from the orchestra, mingled with solemn sounds.

The screen rises, and we see the glorious Roman Capitol. The stage is empty, except for Clio, the Muse of History on one side, and next to her, a goddess with a trumpet representing Fame. We hear the Trojan March sound out, transmitted by tradition to become the triumphal chant of the Romans.
We see passing before the Capitol a warrior in shining armor at the head of several Roman legions.

sp.speaker: CLIO
sp.l: Scipio the African! Glory!
sp.stage: Another warrior, crowned with laurels, passes by, marching at the head of more legions.

sp.speaker: CLIO
sp.l: Julius Caesar! Glory!
sp.stage: We see an emperor surrounded by a court of poets and artists.

sp.speaker: CLIO
sp.l: Emperor Augustus and the poet Virgil! Glory! Glory!
Troy is no more;
Now, Rome!

sp.speaker: A SOPRANO
sp.stage: backstage
sp.l: Now, Rome!

sp.speaker: A TENOR
sp.stage: farther away
sp.l: Now, Rome!
